title: Cypress Basics Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of Cypress fundamentals

questions.question: Which company developed Cypress?
questions.explanation: Cypress was developed by Cypress.io (now just Cypress) and was first released in 2015. It's a JavaScript-centric testing framework.

questions.question: What type of tests is Cypress primarily designed for?
questions.explanation: Cypress is primarily designed for end-to-end testing of web applications. It simulates real user interactions in a real browser.

questions.question: Cypress runs tests in the same execution loop as the application.
questions.explanation: Unlike Selenium, Cypress runs in the same execution loop as the application, giving it access to everything in the browser and allowing for faster, more reliable tests.

questions.question: Which language are Cypress tests written in?
questions.explanation: Cypress tests are written entirely in JavaScript or TypeScript, allowing full access to JavaScript APIs and frameworks.

questions.question: What is the command to open Cypress Test Runner?
questions.explanation: The 'cypress open' command launches the Cypress Test Runner, which provides an interactive GUI for running and debugging tests.

questions.question: What does the 'cy' prefix represent in Cypress commands?

options.text: It's the Cypress namespace for all commands

questions.explanation: All Cypress commands are prefixed with 'cy', which is the Cypress namespace. This distinguishes Cypress commands from other JavaScript code.

questions.question: Which command is used to select an element in Cypress?
questions.explanation: cy.get() is the primary command for selecting elements in Cypress. It accepts CSS selectors and returns a chainable Cypress object.

questions.question: Cypress automatically waits for elements to exist before performing actions.
questions.explanation: Cypress has automatic waiting built in. It automatically waits for elements to exist in the DOM and for animations to complete before performing actions.

questions.question: What is the default command timeout in Cypress?
questions.explanation: The default timeout for most Cypress commands is 4 seconds. This can be configured globally or overridden per command using the timeout option.

questions.question: You need to test that clicking a 'Submit' button shows a success message. What Cypress code would you use?
questions.explanation: In Cypress, you chain commands: click the button, then get the success message element, then assert it should be visible. Assertions are made with 'should' or 'expect'.

questions.question: Which file contains the Cypress configuration?
questions.explanation: In newer Cypress versions (10+), configuration is in cypress.config.js or cypress.config.ts. In older versions, it was cypress.json.

questions.question: Cypress can test API endpoints directly without a browser.
questions.explanation: Cypress can make HTTP requests using cy.request() to test API endpoints directly, without needing to go through the browser UI.

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'cy.intercept()'?

options.text: To stub or spy on network requests

questions.explanation: cy.intercept() is used to intercept, stub, and spy on network requests and responses. It can mock API calls or monitor network traffic.

questions.question: What are Cypress 'hooks'?

options.text: before(), beforeEach(), after(), afterEach() methods for setup/teardown

questions.explanation: Hooks in Cypress are methods that run before or after tests: before(), beforeEach(), after(), and afterEach(). They help set up test conditions and clean up after tests.

options.text: It only types in username field
It fills a login form and submits it

questions.explanation: This code fills in a username and password field using type(), then submits the form using cy.get('form').submit(), which is equivalent to pressing enter on the form.

questions.question: Which command is used to assert text content in Cypress?
questions.explanation: Both cy.contains() and assertions with .should('contain', 'text') can be used to check text content. cy.contains() is often simpler for finding elements by text.

questions.question: Cypress supports multiple browsers including Chrome, Firefox, and Edge.
questions.explanation: Cypress supports multiple browsers including Chrome, Firefox, Edge, and WebKit (experimental). Run 'cypress open' to select a browser.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Cypress 'fixtures'?

options.text: To store and load external data for tests

questions.explanation: Fixtures are used to store external pieces of data (like JSON files) that can be loaded into tests. They're useful for test data management and data-driven testing.

questions.question: You need to test that a loading spinner appears and then disappears after data loads. How would you test this?
questions.explanation: You can chain Cypress assertions: first check the spinner is visible, then check it no longer exists after the data loads. Cypress will wait for the 'not.exist' condition.

questions.question: What is the main limitation of Cypress compared to Selenium?

options.text: Cypress only works with JavaScript apps and cannot test iframes or cross-origin requests easily

questions.explanation: Cypress has some limitations: it only supports JavaScript/TypeScript, has difficulty with iframes, and cannot handle multi-tab or cross-origin requests easily due to its architecture.
